docs.lead_paragraph: Older women have no greater risk of bearing children with many of the commonest birth defects than do younger women, and may even have a lower chance of giving birth to babies with three common congenital deformities, a new study has found. The report, which examined nearly 27,000 cases of birth defects, seems to contradict the conventional wisdom that women play a kind of Russian roulette with their future offspring when they postpone motherhood beyond the age of 35. The analysis does not include cases of Down syndrome, which are known to be more prevalent among older women.

headline.main: Study Finds Older Women Are at No Greater Risk in Bearing Children With Defects
